awd_titl_txt: Linking Violence and Migration and Individual and Household Safety and Well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is a study of the violence-migration relationship in communities across Latin America and the United States.  All levels of the relationship are considered:  individual decision making, characteristics of sending and receiving communities, and how migration patterns link communities together.  The central questions address the migration behavior of individuals and households and how migration patterns affect both sending and receiving communities.  The research extends the empirical and conceptual literatures across a range of substantive areas including crime, demography, migration, neighborhood studies, and network analysis. The broader impacts of the study include understanding questions of interest to policy makers and scholars, particularly those seeking to understand how migration hinders or increases safety.  In addition, the project will support the development of a collaborative interdisciplinary research network and the training of future researchers.

This project creates a comprehensive multilevel and multinational data file spanning twenty years that links aggregate data on migration and safety to a wealth of individual, household, and community data. Innovative modeling techniques allow for 1) an assessment of the relationship between migration and  changes (improvements or reductions) in safety in receiving communities, 2) an examination of if and how migration networks are associated with spatiotemporal patterns in crime, 3) specific tests for individual, family, and community variability in the responsiveness of migration to changes in perceptions of safety, as well as 4) a consideration of how safety and migration can change and re-shape sending communities. Network-based and spatial econometric tools overcome several methodological issues identified in earlier work.

por.por_cntn:
This multiyear study of violence in Mexico, migration, and crime was motivated by growing concerns about the displacement of Mexican residents. Between 2007 and 2010, the homicide rate in Mexico more than doubled and remained elevated into 2020. This research investigated migration caused by these events, the circumstances that hindered or escalated migration, and whether patterns of migration resulting from exposure to violence differed across population subgroups: older versus younger people, those with more or less education, and those with different levels of economic resources. We also investigated how violence, and the departure of people from communities, changed features of community life in Mexico.  

The research supported the graduate training of three students, two in sociology and one in economics. The funding also supported the production of spatially-referenced data with help from the University of Wisconsin's Applied Population Laboratory. Using these data, we produced four studies that address the aims above. Each of the studies is co-authored by one of the graduate students on the research team.

The research resulted in several findings. We concluded that the escalation of violence in Mexico did not dramatically increase the flow of migrants to the United States. Though exposure to violence did increase the probability of interregional migration within Mexico, and for some groups, migration to the U.S., the effects are small in magnitude. We also conclude that the migration of people resulting from exposure to violence did not result in the "export" of criminal activity to the U.S. The small effects of violence on migration differentially induced people to move to the U.S. in several population subgroups with a lower likelihood of committing violent crime. The findings instead support a contributing explanation for the inverse relationship between migration and crime in cities across the U.S. We conclude that this relationship arises in part from migrant selectivity--i.e., U.S. immigrants are "selected" in ways that result in lowered probability of committing violent crime. We demonstrate that this selectivity was, if anything, heightened by exposure to violence in Mexican sending communities.

We found that increases in violence changed features of community life in Mexico, including collective efficacy and sociality. The magnitude of these effects differed in important ways by the level of violence occurring in the mid-2000s, prior to the 2008-2010 escalation. We documented the doubling of femicide--the murder of women--in Mexico during this same period. We observed that the increase was largely driven by violence outside of the home. We linked vital records data to repeated cross-sectional survey data on people's experience of interpersonal violence in relationships. By analyzing these data, we found little evidence that public violence increased the risk of interpersonal violence in relationships, even in partnerships among young adults who spent adolescence with elevated exposure to violent crime in their daily lives.

We have presented the findings of this work in multiple venues, for both academic and policy audiences.
